ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned largely about the mechanics of academia - for example how research is conducted, presented and published.

This course provided me knowledge of researching and writing in a graduate setting. This course was very helpful for incoming master's students to help us get acclimated to the expectations of the European and Russian Studies program.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A little unfocused. A lot of the students are doing very different things, though the speakers were very interesting. Hard to find common ground for everyone.

The course was a helpful introduction to graduate study. It was great hearing from guests from different corners of academia that young scholars don't often consider. I would recommend further engagement especially with the research process, giving more consideration to approaches to our theses. A class on securing funding, for instance, would be very useful.

The various speakers brought in throughout the semester provided insight into different areas of research, writing, and publishing and was very helpful in showing a broad range of research and writing styles.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: You have to take it, but it's still good to get an idea of what people are doing.

I'm glad to have taken this course. It expected a fair amount from us while still providing a lot of insight, especially in being able to navigate academia and Yale. It was also great having a setting to meet with fellow European and Russian Studies students.
Even though the course is required, I highly recommend it to incoming E&RS students as it is very helpful in acclimating new students to the expectations of the master's degree.
